title: Psalms Chapter 113 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 113 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 113 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 113.

questions.question: Who is called to praise the name of the LORD in Psalms 113:1?
questions.correctAnswer: The servants of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:1 calls on 'ye servants of the LORD' to praise His name.

questions.question: According to Psalms 113:2, how long is the name of the LORD to be blessed?
options: From this time forth and for evermore
Until the end of the year
questions.correctAnswer: From this time forth and for evermore
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:2 says the name of the LORD is blessed from this time forth and forevermore.

questions.question: When is the LORD's name to be praised according to Psalms 113:3?
options: From the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same
questions.correctAnswer: From the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:3 instructs to praise the LORD's name from sunrise to sunset.

questions.question: Where is the LORD said to be high above in Psalms 113:4?
questions.correctAnswer: All nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:4 states the LORD is high above all nations.

questions.question: What is the LORD's glory above according to Psalms 113:4?
questions.correctAnswer: The heavens
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:4 says the LORD's glory is above the heavens.

questions.question: Who is like unto the LORD our God according to Psalms 113:5?
questions.correctAnswer: No one
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:5 asks who is like the LORD our God, implying no one is like Him.

questions.question: Where does the LORD dwell according to Psalms 113:5?
questions.correctAnswer: On high
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:5 describes the LORD as dwelling on high.

questions.question: What does the LORD humble himself to behold according to Psalms 113:6?
options: The things that are in heaven and in the earth
questions.correctAnswer: The things that are in heaven and in the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:6 states the LORD humbles himself to behold things in heaven and earth.

questions.question: According to Psalms 113:7, who does the LORD raise up?
options: The poor out of the dust
questions.correctAnswer: The poor out of the dust
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:7 says the LORD raises the poor out of the dust.

questions.question: What phrase completes this verse from Psalms 113:7: 'He raiseth up the poor out of the dust, and lifteth the needy out of the ______'?
questions.correctAnswer: dunghill
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:7 uses the phrase 'lifteth the needy out of the dunghill'.

questions.question: According to Psalms 113:8, with whom does God set the needy?
questions.correctAnswer: Princes
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:8 states God sets the needy with princes.

questions.question: What does the LORD make the barren woman do according to Psalms 113:9?
options: Keep house and be a joyful mother of children
questions.correctAnswer: Keep house and be a joyful mother of children
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:9 says the LORD makes the barren woman keep house and be joyful mother.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 113:1 begins with a call to praise the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:1 starts with 'Praise ye the LORD.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 113:6, the LORD only looks down upon the things on earth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:6 states the LORD beholds things in heaven and earth, not only earth.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 113:4 says the LORD's glory is below the heavens.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:4 says the LORD's glory is above the heavens.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 113 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 113 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of insignificance and low self-worth. Based on Psalms 113, what biblical truth would you share about God's view of the needy?
options: God lifts the needy out of the dust and sets them with princes
God ignores the poor and needy in their distress
God only cares for the righteous and wealthy
God expects the poor to earn their place without help
questions.correctAnswer: God lifts the needy out of the dust and sets them with princes
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:7-8 teaches that God raises the poor and needy from lowly conditions and places them with princes, showing God's care and elevation of those who are humble and in need.

questions.question: How does Psalms 113 encourage believers to maintain a spirit of praise throughout their daily lives?
options: Praise the LORD from sunrise to sunset
Only praise the LORD on special occasions
Praise the LORD only when you feel happy
Praise the LORD quietly without others knowing
questions.correctAnswer: Praise the LORD from sunrise to sunset
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:3 emphasizes praising the LORD continually from the rising of the sun to its going down, encouraging ongoing devotion and gratitude throughout the day.

questions.question: A believer is feeling overwhelmed by their circumstances and wonders if God notices their struggles. According to Psalms 113, how can you encourage them about God's attention?
options: God humbles Himself to behold the things in heaven and earth
God is too high to notice earthly troubles
God only focuses on great nations and leaders
God is indifferent to individual needs
questions.correctAnswer: God humbles Himself to behold the things in heaven and earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:6 reveals that although God dwells on high, He humbles Himself to see and care for all things, including individual struggles, encouraging trust in His attentiveness.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 113, what can married couples learn about God's blessing in family life?
options: God makes the barren woman a joyful mother of children
God only blesses families with wealth
questions.correctAnswer: God makes the barren woman a joyful mother of children
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:9 highlights God's power to bless barren women with children, affirming His involvement in family life and encouraging faith in His provision and joy in parenting.

questions.question: How does Psalms 113 teach believers about humility in their relationship with God?
options: God Himself humbles to behold His creation
Believers should elevate themselves above others
God demands pride from His servants
questions.correctAnswer: God Himself humbles to behold His creation
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:6 shows God's humility as He looks upon the earth and heaven, teaching believers the value of humility in their own lives and relationship with God.

questions.question: A church leader is preparing a message on the greatness of God. How does Psalms 113 describe God's position relative to nations and heavens?
options: The LORD is high above all nations and His glory above the heavens
God is equal to earthly kings and rulers
God's glory is limited to Israel only
God is hidden and unknown to nations
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is high above all nations and His glory above the heavens
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:4 declares God's supreme exaltation above all nations and the heavens, affirming His sovereignty and glory over all creation.

questions.question: What does Psalms 113 say about the consistency of praising God's name?
options: Blessed be the name of the LORD from this time forth and forevermore
Praise only during festivals and celebrations
Praise only when God answers prayers
Praise only in private, not publicly
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed be the name of the LORD from this time forth and forevermore
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:2 emphasizes that God's name is to be blessed and praised continually, without end, encouraging ongoing worship and gratitude.

questions.question: A believer is questioning how God values those who serve Him. According to Psalms 113, what is the appropriate response of God's servants?
options: Praise the name of the LORD
Focus on personal gain instead of praising God
Praise only when things go well
questions.correctAnswer: Praise the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:1 calls on the servants of the LORD to praise His name, teaching the importance of active worship and devotion as a response to God's goodness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 113 encourage believers to view God's care for the lowly and needy in society?
options: God raises the poor from the dust and the needy from the dunghill
God ignores the poor and needy
God prefers the wealthy over the poor
God expects the poor to rely only on themselves
questions.correctAnswer: God raises the poor from the dust and the needy from the dunghill
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:7 teaches that God actively lifts the poor and needy from lowly conditions, reassuring believers of God's concern for all social classes.

questions.question: What does Psalms 113 teach about God's relationship with those who serve Him in daily devotion?
options: God is worthy of continual praise throughout the day
God only accepts praise on the Sabbath
God prefers praise only from the wealthy
God does not require praise from His servants
questions.correctAnswer: God is worthy of continual praise throughout the day
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:3 encourages praising God from morning until evening, underscoring the importance of daily devotion and consistent worship.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment in their family life. How does Psalms 113 provide encouragement regarding God’s blessings in the home?
options: God makes the barren woman a joyful mother of children
God discourages joy in family life
God only blesses those with many children
God’s blessings are unrelated to family
questions.correctAnswer: God makes the barren woman a joyful mother of children
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:9 demonstrates God's power to bring joy and blessing in family life, especially to those who long for children, encouraging faith and gratitude.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 113, God’s glory is above the heavens, showing His supreme majesty.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:4 states that the LORD’s glory is above the heavens, signifying His supreme majesty and exalted position.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 113 teaches that God is indifferent to the condition of the poor and needy.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:7-8 clearly teaches that God lifts the poor out of the dust and the needy out of the dunghill, showing His care and concern for them.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Who is like unto the LORD our God, who dwelleth on ____, Who humbleth himself to behold the things that are in heaven, and in the earth!"
questions.correctAnswer: high
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:5-6 states that the LORD dwells on high and humbles Himself to behold creation, highlighting His exalted yet humble nature.

questions.question: How does Psalms 113 teach believers about the importance of praising God in their church fellowship?
options: Servants of the LORD are called to praise His name together
Praise is a private act and should not be done publicly
Only priests are allowed to praise God
Praise is unnecessary in church gatherings
questions.correctAnswer: Servants of the LORD are called to praise His name together
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:1 encourages the servants of the LORD—His people—to praise His name, underscoring the communal aspect of worship in the church.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 113 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 113.

questions.question: What is the repeated imperative given to the servants of the LORD in Psalms 113:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Praise the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:1 commands, 'Praise ye the LORD. Praise, O ye servants of the LORD, praise the name of the LORD.' The imperative is to praise.

questions.question: According to Psalms 113:2, how long is the name of the LORD to be blessed?
options: From this time forth and for evermore
Until the end of the day
questions.correctAnswer: From this time forth and for evermore
questions.explanation: Verse 2 states, 'Blessed be the name of the LORD from this time forth and for evermore,' indicating perpetual blessing.

questions.question: The phrase 'From the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same' in Psalms 113:3 signifies what theological concept?
options: Universal and continuous praise of the LORD
The limitation of God's power to daytime
The importance of the sun in worship
questions.correctAnswer: Universal and continuous praise of the LORD
questions.explanation: This phrase in verse 3 emphasizes that the LORD's name is to be praised everywhere and at all times, indicating universal worship.

questions.question: In Psalms 113:4, the LORD is described as being high above all nations and His glory above what?
questions.correctAnswer: The heavens
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states, 'The LORD is high above all nations, and his glory above the heavens,' indicating supreme divine exaltation.

questions.question: Which literary device is most evident in Psalms 113:5-6, where the LORD is described as dwelling on high yet humbling Himself to behold the earth?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The structure of the phrases in verses 5-6 forms a chiasm: God is exalted (dwells on high) and humbles Himself (beholds lowly things), showing a mirrored structure.

questions.question: What Hebrew word, often translated as 'humbleth' in Psalms 113:6, conveys the idea of stooping or bending down?
questions.correctAnswer: Anah
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'Anah' used here signifies stooping or humbling oneself, emphasizing God's condescension to observe creation (Psalm 113:6).

questions.question: In Psalms 113:7, what social class does the LORD raise up 'out of the dust'?
questions.correctAnswer: The poor
questions.explanation: Verse 7 explicitly states, 'He raiseth up the poor out of the dust,' indicating God's care for the lowly.

questions.question: Psalms 113:8 uses the phrase 'even with the princes of his people.' What theme does this emphasize?
options: God's elevation of the lowly to positions of honor
The exclusivity of the priestly class
The power of earthly kings over the poor
questions.correctAnswer: God's elevation of the lowly to positions of honor
questions.explanation: Verse 8 shows God's justice and mercy by raising the needy to stand among princes, highlighting divine reversal of social status.

questions.question: How does the promise in Psalms 113:9 relate to Old Testament themes of fertility and blessing?
options: It fulfills the blessing of progeny as a sign of God's favor
It condemns barrenness as a curse
It refers to agricultural fertility only
It emphasizes celibacy as a spiritual ideal
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfills the blessing of progeny as a sign of God's favor
questions.explanation: Verse 9 describes making the barren woman a joyful mother, connecting to biblical themes where children signify blessing and covenantal favor.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 113 emphasizes that God's glory is limited to the heavens and does not extend to the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: While verse 4 says God's glory is above the heavens, verses 6-9 show God humbling Himself to the earth and raising the needy, indicating His glory extends to all creation.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage reflects the theme of God lifting the lowly, as expressed in Psalms 113:7-8?
questions.correctAnswer: Luke 1:52
questions.explanation: Luke 1:52 echoes this theme: 'He hath put down the mighty from their seats, and exalted them of low degree,' paralleling Psalm 113's exaltation of the poor.

questions.question: The call to 'Praise ye the LORD' in Psalms 113:1-3 is an example of which Hebrew poetic device?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Verses 1-3 show synonymous parallelism, repeating the command to praise and the reason for praise, characteristic of Hebrew poetry.

questions.question: In Psalms 113:9, the phrase 'He maketh the barren woman to keep house' can be interpreted as what type of biblical motif?
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration and hope
questions.explanation: The barrenness being reversed into joyful motherhood symbolizes restoration, a motif often used to show God's transformative power.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural practice contrasts with the depiction of God in Psalms 113:7-8, who raises the needy to princely status?
options: Rigid social hierarchies with divine kingship legitimizing elites
questions.correctAnswer: Rigid social hierarchies with divine kingship legitimizing elites
questions.explanation: Unlike many ancient cultures where kingship reinforced elite status, Psalm 113 highlights God's reversal of social order by lifting the poor and needy.

questions.question: The exaltation of God's name 'from the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same' in Psalms 113:3 foreshadows which concept found in Revelation 7:9?
options: Universal worship before the throne of God
The final judgment of the nations
The establishment of a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: Universal worship before the throne of God
questions.explanation: Revelation 7:9 depicts a great multitude from all nations worshiping God, echoing Psalm 113's theme of praise throughout the world and all times.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 113 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 113 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 113:1, who is called upon to praise the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Servants of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:1 explicitly calls "ye servants of the LORD" to praise God's name, emphasizing the role of God's faithful servants in worship. This is consistent with other scriptures such as Romans 6:22, where believers are called servants of righteousness, and Revelation 7:15, where God's servants praise Him continually.

questions.question: What is declared about the name of the LORD in Psalms 113:2?
options: Blessed from this time forth and forevermore
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed from this time forth and forevermore
questions.explanation: Psalms 113:2 states that the name of the LORD is to be blessed eternally. This eternal blessing aligns with Malachi 1:11 and Hebrews 13:15, where God's name is praised continually across all generations.

questions.question: Psalms 113:3 emphasizes praise from when to when?
options: From the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same
From the first day to the last
From the east to the west
questions.correctAnswer: From the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same
questions.explanation: The verse calls for continuous praise throughout the day, symbolizing unceasing worship. This perpetual praise theme is echoed in Psalm 134:1 and Luke 24:53, where worship is extended throughout all times.

questions.question: According to Psalms 113:4, how is the LORD described in relation to nations and heavens?
options: High above all nations and His glory above the heavens
Equal with all nations and among the stars
Hidden among the nations and beneath the heavens
Separate from the nations and distant from the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: High above all nations and His glory above the heavens
questions.explanation: The LORD’s transcendence over all creation is affirmed here, consistent with Isaiah 57:15 and 1 Timothy 6:15, which describe God as sovereign over all nations and exalted above the heavens.

questions.question: What rhetorical question is posed in Psalms 113:5 about the LORD?
options: Who is like unto the LORD our God?
Who shall ascend the hill of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Who is like unto the LORD our God?
questions.explanation: This question highlights God's uniqueness and incomparable nature, echoed in Exodus 15:11 and Isaiah 40:18, emphasizing there is no one like the LORD.

questions.question: Psalms 113:6 describes God as one who does what to behold creation?
options: Humbles Himself to behold the things that are in heaven and in the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Humbles Himself to behold the things that are in heaven and in the earth
questions.explanation: This verse reveals God's condescension and immanence, showing His willingness to engage with His creation. Philippians 2:6-7 and Hebrews 4:15 similarly describe God’s humility and presence with humanity.

questions.question: What act of divine mercy is highlighted in Psalms 113:7?
options: He raises up the poor out of the dust
He hides His face from sinners
questions.correctAnswer: He raises up the poor out of the dust
questions.explanation: This verse underscores God's care for the lowly and needy, consistent with James 2:5 and Luke 1:52, affirming God's justice and mercy towards the humble.

questions.question: Psalms 113:8 explains God's purpose in lifting the needy. What is it?
options: That He may set him with princes
That He may humble the proud
That He may test their faith
That He may hide them from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: That He may set him with princes
questions.explanation: God exalts the lowly to positions of honor, signifying divine reversal of human status, as also seen in Luke 1:52 and 1 Samuel 2:8, demonstrating God’s sovereign justice.

questions.question: In Psalms 113:9, what blessing does God bestow upon the barren woman?
options: Makes her a joyful mother of children
questions.correctAnswer: Makes her a joyful mother of children
questions.explanation: This verse reveals God's power over life and blessing, transforming barrenness to fruitfulness, which aligns with Genesis 21:1-3 and Luke 1:7, affirming God's ability to grant new life.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most emphasized throughout Psalms 113?
options: His exaltation and mercy toward the lowly
questions.correctAnswer: His exaltation and mercy toward the lowly
questions.explanation: The psalm highlights God's supreme exaltation and His compassionate lifting of the poor, consistent with Proverbs 3:34 and Matthew 5:3-5, demonstrating God's justice and grace.

questions.question: What theological concept is reflected by God humbling Himself to behold creation in Psalms 113:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine condescension
questions.explanation: God’s humility in engaging with His creation is a key doctrine of condescension, also taught in Philippians 2:6-8 and John 1:14, where God the Son took on human form.

questions.question: How does Psalms 113:4 contribute to the doctrine of God's transcendence?
options: By stating the LORD is high above all nations and His glory above the heavens
By saying the LORD dwells among men
By describing the LORD as a warrior
By claiming the LORD is a consuming fire
questions.correctAnswer: By stating the LORD is high above all nations and His glory above the heavens
questions.explanation: This verse affirms God's absolute transcendence over creation, a foundational attribute described also in Isaiah 57:15 and Psalm 147:5, emphasizing God’s majesty and sovereignty.

questions.question: What messianic theme can be drawn from God raising the needy to be among princes in Psalms 113:8?
options: God’s kingdom will exalt the humble through the Messiah
The Messiah will only rule over the rich
The Messiah will ignore the poor
The Messiah will abolish earthly kingdoms
questions.correctAnswer: God’s kingdom will exalt the humble through the Messiah
questions.explanation: This reflects the kingdom reversal theme seen in Luke 1:52 and Matthew 5:5, where the Messiah elevates the lowly, fulfilling God’s promise of justice and restoration.

questions.question: Which aspect of salvation is illustrated by God making the barren woman joyful in Psalms 113:9?
options: God’s power to bring new life
questions.correctAnswer: God’s power to bring new life
questions.explanation: This verse symbolizes God’s redemptive power to transform hopelessness into joy, paralleling Hannah’s story in 1 Samuel 1:20 and Elizabeth in Luke 1:14.

questions.question: What does the continuous praise from sunrise to sunset in Psalms 113:3 imply about God's nature?
options: God is worthy of continual worship at all times
God is only present during daylight
God is unknown in the night
questions.correctAnswer: God is worthy of continual worship at all times
questions.explanation: The perpetual praise signifies God’s unchanging nature and infinite worthiness, supported by Revelation 4:8 and Psalm 145:2, which call for ceaseless worship.
